subject: RE: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()

messageBody:
Dear David,



First off, I apologize if my formatting makes this e-mail hard to read.
I have been having trouble getting the formatting to work over the
listserv. Secondly, I apologize if I come off as overly assertive:
since I have recently returned to JUnit after years of using NUnit, I
realize that I probably have an opinion that outpaces my community
contribution thus far. But, here goes nothing J.



>The API confusion from introducing assertThat(b) seems a bigger loss
than the gain in Englishness.



I strongly disagree. One of the great strengths of the Hamcrest system
is the natural readability and self-documentation of the asserts, and
the proposed change only enhances that. It's important to look at these
use cases from the point of view of the user. For example, in the
following examples



assertThat(list.isEmpty());

assertThat(flagNotSet);

assertThat(objectIsNull && listIsEmpty);



the intent of the tester is very easy to understand. By contrast, in
statements with matchers, the names of the matchers are such that the
tester's different intent becomes clear very quickly. For example, the
following examples



assertThat(list, contains("JUnit", "is", "great!"));

assertThat(string, is("Hello, World!"));



state very clearly that their intention is different from a simple
boolean check.



In sum, the assertThat functionality is a great step forward for JUnit,
and I strongly encourage it to be expanded as Martijn suggested. This
is one of the features that makes JUnit great to work with, and one of
the features whose expansion would most benefit end users and add to the
value of JUnit as a product.



Again, sorry if I sound overly assertive here: it's hard to disagree as
a newcomer without sounding aggressive.



Thank you,



Rocco



From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Wednesday, May 13, 2009 9:25 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or
IsCollection.isEmpty()








I believe that the hamcrest distro does have assertThat that aliases
assertTrue. However, I don't like the pseudo-parallelism of:

assertTrue(b)
assertThat(b) // means the same thing as assertTrue(b)
assertThat(o, m) // means something very different

The API confusion from introducing assertThat(b) seems a bigger loss
than the gain in Englishness.

David Saff
